text: hi everyone
Anthony Fantana here internet's busiest
music nerd time for an album review
pallbearer
sorrow and extinction pallbearer is a
name that not only brings me back to my
younger years where I watched a lot of
Pro Wrestling but it's also the name of
an Arkansas band in Arkansas metal band
this is their debut LP and there's not
too much backstory to give on these guys
other than that they landed a deal on
profound lore records which is one of
the best underground metal labels out
there right now based on some of the
great song writing on a three track demo
that they released in 2010 and though
this demo who was good the studio
recording on this band's new LP brings
their traditional doom metal sound to
new levels of heaviness and melody I
said traditional doom metal where low
end frequencies reign supreme and when
it comes to riffs the slower the better
I'm talking about bands like Candlemas
trouble and of course Black Sabbath but
obviously making music in 2012
pallbearer has the ability to reach low
heavy sounds that these groups could
only dream of making when they first
started releasing albums
well the production the recording on
this thing is fantastic the riffs are
massive they're crushing kind of like
Giles Corey the man not the album
getting smothered to death by rocks
placed on him by colonialists accusing
him voyage craft the riffs just had this
really grinding rough quality to them
it's like hearing a never ending
monstrous roar only having volume and
only having
having this is not going to be enough to
you know get your album buy and keep it
interesting when other sounds come into
the mix I think that's where pallbearer
really puts their own spin on this stuff
really pulls together a personality and
creates a style of traditional doom
metal that I think will even appeal to
people who are usually not into this
kind of music the sounds of psychedelic
and progressive rock make their way onto
this LP and for a doom metal band
pallbearer is incredibly incredibly
melodic to the point where the melodies
being played by the guitars on these
tracks take the spotlight more than the
heaviness of these songs the melody and
the beauty of this LP comes out right at
the start of the first track with this a
acoustic guitar intro which is very
somber very pretty then this wave of
feedback kind of jumps in and then the
heavy riffs start
they are so gargantuan they're just
panoramic sounding just surrounding me
as I hear them the sound is almost
tangible rumbling but over these heavy
riffs these harmonized guitar solos just
soar it's like sunrays peeking through
all these dark storm clouds that's not
all because the riffs that are being
played under these really great guitar
solos and guitar harmonies guitar leads
are pretty lengthy not your average doom
metal riff not down now now the riffs
are as interesting to listen to on the
opening track as the guitar solos
themselves and there's some really nice
drum fills on this track too I love the
way the drums sort of play around the
riff I love the way they syncopate with
the riff from time to time there's
definitely some good interplay going on
another thing I think is great about the
track is just the vocals there's some
very cleanly and have a lot of drama to
them they're a little strained here and
there but there's some well and
sometimes this harmony will pop in and
it just sounds really moving especially
when it's just escalating to its limit
it's almost as if I'm listening to a
heavier take on progressive rock acts
like King Crimson or Jethro Tull and
keep in mind this is all just in the
first song which is 12 minutes long and
really engaging from start to finish the
following track though devoid of
redemption is much more straightforward
the riff is more repetitive but the band
kind of throws a curveball on this track
by throwing some psychedelic elements
into the song after the second track the
album hits kind of a dry spot I guess
because the third song on here while it
is heavy it doesn't really bring
anything the previous couple tracks
didn't already be and there's just
something about the vocal delivery on
that track that just felt I guess a
little forced that time around though I
know I am kind of making a big deal out
of just one single song it is one of
just five songs on this entire album and
spans to almost nine minutes the next
track on here an offering of grief
doesn't really expand on the ideas of
the previous two tracks either but at
least has more variation than the third
the final song on here continues to
break things up a little bit more quiet
interludes there's a keyboard on here
that sounds a little bit like a
Mellotron - and even though it does
sound different instrumentally just kind
of felt like window dressing I guess
because of the core these songs are
written essentially with the same exact
intentions as the previous tracks
pallbearer just kind of ran out of new
ideas to introduce me to which just kind
of made this album feel like it dragged
on like it was longer than it it needed
to be which is silly because it's not
even 50 minutes long it drowns in its
influences a little bit runs out of
ideas a little too fast but still adds
up to a very listenable debut album that
I would recommend to anyone who's into
this style kind of feeling a decent too
strong 7 what do you think about it if
you've heard it let me know love it hate
it why and what should I
II review next Anthony Fantino
pallbearer forever
